It looks good to me! I think we should let this patch land and implement missing features in separate patches.'}, {'account_id': 5347, 'date': '2013-08-08 14:19:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

As Flavio says, we'll fill in the remaining holes with separate patches. I think that's a good plan."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-08 19:59:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

At the end of the day, I don't think glanceclient should be supporting this old interface from nova. It just doesn't really seem to be the right way to conceptualize a remote image service, and it tries to lump v2 and v1 together behind the same interface by default, which seems strange to me. 

So I'm in the camp that to share this code, we probably should put it in oslo.

I apologize for the lateness of my review."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-08 22:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

After the glance-meeting today, I want to ask the ironic folks, what about this particular image service abstraction is better for them than using the client libraries glanceclient has right now?

Going through this review, it seems like an image service provides access to list, get, update, delete, download, and upload an image--these are all things that ironic could do directly using existing code in glanceclient. Is there any reason for ironic not to just use the existing code in glanceclient directly?'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-08 23:35:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Do not merge

Please do not take the -2 too harshly.  I am willing to change my mind but I would really like these points addressed before this is merged.

As far as I understand it, the ImageService abstraction in Nova provided two things:

1) An driver interface.  The same interface can be used to speak to S3 and possibly others.

2) An alternative interface to the one provided by python-glanceclient.

#1 clearly does not apply to the glance client.  It would not make a lot of sense to have the a glance client speak to S3.  That would be a broken abstraction.  Further, it would not make sense to have the interface to a storage system abstraction live inside of one of the implementation.  I could be wrong, but this patch appears to do this.  The question is, if this were moved here, what interface would the S3 driver implement?  It looks to me like it would inherit from glanceclient.common.service.ImageService, which seems broken.

WRT #2 I have the same concerns as markwash.  Why not use  the API already offered by python-glanceclient?  There very well could be a good reason for this but I would like to frame the discussion more in those terms (ie: what is the current API missing), and less in the terms of 'nova and cinder repeat themselves'.

A final point is that the code added here is not in sync with the current nova code base."}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2013-08-09 09:56:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

As I  understand it, there are some cases when is neccessary a wrapper like this:
- glanceclient api v1 and v2 are different, and even how to use them differ. From an program point of view (nova, ironic..,) this can be an issue, and means they will have to duplicate the code. What is now in nova is even worse, because the mix v1 and v2 calls depending on what is needed. Having a wrapper on top of it, can facilitate a migration or version selection without having to care about it on the programs that use it. 
- This wrapper right now, covers the minimum basic image manipulation (crud) and that's just what is needed by cinder, ironic and nova programs, and only some corner cases are missing (like tags manipulation), but can be added after that.
- If at some time, others storage services are added (like S3), creating a similar wrapper for those is feasible, and easy to integrate on programs.

What this wrapper also add to the basic glanceclient is:
- api calls can be retried a configured number of times
- ensure that image service endpoint are correct, some params are properly json encoded/decoded, do some filters 
- On the roadmap: get that endpoint from keystone services endpoints

Other issues:
- These service is out of sync with the one in nova because, as said earlier, nova have a mix of v1 and v2 calls, and when porting it, this was replaced by differentiating both apis.
- get_api_servers is a remain of the nova version, but I also agree that could be removed. HA should be done outside glance.

Thanks all for the feedback."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-09 16:13:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Ghe,

Can Ironic just use v2? I don't know why it would need to use v1, but if there's a missing feature I'd prefer to fix it in the v2 client rather than make a generic adapter that works with both v1 and v2. To me, v1 and v2 are different creatures and I don't see a reason for a new project to try to abstract out the similarities.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-09 16:38:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Ghe,

Thanks for the well thought out feedback!  It sounds like you have a set of feature request for glanceclient.

1) a single interface for both v1 and v2
2) a configurable number of retries
3) better parameter checking

Those seem like reasonable things (noting that Mark has a reasonable problem with #1).  However, this patch seems to be doing more than that.

I don't think it would ever be appropriate to have an S3 (or any other non-glance protocol) client implementation inside of Glance client, thus I am not sure what the point of glanceclient.common.service.ImageService is.  From what it does in nova I have to assume its purpose is to provide an interface behind which you can implement many protocols.  As I mentioned that does not make sense in Glance client.

Also the part of nova which I was concerned with being in sync come from this patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37817/"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-17 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-17 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Move glance image service client from nova and cinder.

This is now present in nova and cinder, and it will be also needed in ironic,
so moving it into a common location.

Most of the code was present on nova.image.glance and cinder.image.glance.

glanceclient/exc.py => nova.exception <=> cinder.exception
 GlanceBaseException
 GlanceConnectionFailed
 ImageNotFound
 ImageNotAuthorized
 Invalid

Implements: blueprint image-tools

Change-Id: Ibb2c44df99ae5746e32695e69078737cc6b5aeeb

[{'created': '2013-08-02 06:05:23.000000000', 'message': "Demo for swift-ec project

NB: hacking style to verify some design only

* add example ec lib(FECpp) in common/ec.py
* allow obj-server to read/write 'ec_objects' dir
* load ecobject_ring in proxy/server.py
* filter out ec requests and let specific func to handle

With some basic codes it should be much easier to talk about the
detail design.

Change-Id: I064a523355cfd7dc02178c2332fa57ab715e7846
"}]
commit_message:
Demo for swift-ec project

NB: hacking style to verify some design only

* add example ec lib(FECpp) in common/ec.py
* allow obj-server to read/write 'ec_objects' dir
* load ecobject_ring in proxy/server.py
* filter out ec requests and let specific func to handle

With some basic codes it should be much easier to talk about the
detail design.

Change-Id: I064a523355cfd7dc02178c2332fa57ab715e7846

commit_message:
remove run_filter_once_per_request from GroupAntiAffinityFilter

Now GroupAntiAffinityFilter was defined to run once per request,
but this is not right, as after one VM instance was created, the
field of 'group_hosts' in filter_properties will be updated, and
GroupAntiAffinityFilter will get all 'group_hosts' from
filter_properties to make sure VM instances will not be deployed
on hosts in same 'group_hosts'.

So if there are multiple VMs in one request, the VM deployment
will not obey GroupAntiAffinityFilter, as some VMs might be
deployed on to same host with current VMs.

Fix bug 1206502

Change-Id: I0b663df422605b05d641c64197a3c6db0ac22b74

commit_message:
enable apache2 server as front end for keystone

1.install apache and wsgi module
2.config apache2 vhost and wsgi files for admin and public service.
3.refactor apache functions from horizon and swift into lib/apache

Change-Id: I3a5d1e511c5dca1e6d01a1adca8fda0a43d4f222
Implements: blueprint devstack-setup-apache-keystone

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-02-18 08:56:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I had already started (without knowing of this review) to do that as well for keystone (which I didn't put up for reviews), you may want to have a look at :

https://github.com/chmouel/keystone/commit/7df77623223e32fa108a6cd7bfe0548e998c9c4e"}, {'account_id': 5619, 'date': '2013-02-18 12:46:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I think this middleware doesn't just belong in keystone; our driving usecase requires it for nova, too. Moving it to Oslo, suggests using the Oslo style for middleware configuration.

Comparing to your proposal, I think my implementation is missing:
- You have implemented Access-Control-Expose-Headers.
- You enforce Access-Control-Request-Method
- You only respond with CORS headers if an origin header is present.

Your implementation also implicitly allows 'x-auth-token' and 'content-type', I really prefer this to be explicit from configuration, and IMHO the same applies to Expose-Headers."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-02-18 12:55:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I agree it's better suited for oslo, I have just pointed this out so you may merge the two together."}, {'account_id': 5619, 'date': '2013-02-18 14:11:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5619, 'date': '2013-02-18 14:13:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Add Cors support as a wsgi middleware

This new middleware covers all common Cors usecases. It will (optionally)
respond to preflight OPTIONS requests, and it will add the configured Cross
Origin Resource Sharing headers to all responses to CORS requests. (not just
the preflight request)

Change-Id: Iac9663dd9f3f18fbe600c41778416a7789457b72
Implements: blueprint cors-support
Fixes: bug #987044

There are a lot of rules about token revocation that this misses.  Look at the trust work.  A token issued via OAuth is under the same restrictions as a trust token:  if either  user has an even that would invalidate their tokens, the trust tokens are invalidated as well.  The same must be true for tokens created via OAuth.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-06-21 04:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: (4 inline comments)

Good piece of work.  A few minor comments in-line.  However, I think what is really missing here (unless I have missed it) is the formal proposal for an extension api specification. Termie's is a good description, but we need to turn this into a doc in identity_api repo.  As an example, see the one for the OS-INHERIT extension (https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/openstack-identity-api/v3/src/markdown/identity-api-v3-os-inherit-ext.md). Getting this approved was the first step.  For the oath extension, it should give details of how things like revokation works when keystone users are deleted etc. (to answer some ayoung's questions)"}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-07-06 15:28:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-07-19 01:09:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(9 inline comments)

Since you have implemented a driver/pluggable style system for OAuth backends, I would like to see a base-class for the driver that defines the basic methods expected on such a driver.  The methods should raise exception.NotImplemented() and contain appropriate docstrings for params, types, returns, raises, etc (if possible)

See the Driver object in keystone.token.core for an example."}, {'account_id': 7186, 'date': '2013-07-19 16:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Add delegated_auth support for keystone

Implements an OAuth 1.0a service provider.

blueprint: delegated-auth-via-oauth

DocImpact
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: Ib5561593ab608f3b22fbcd7196e2171f95b735e8

[{'created': '2013-08-16 21:59:36.000000000', 'message': "Echo service start failures.

* functions: Previously screen_it would log service start failures by
touching a file, this isn't very useful when working with Jenkins.
Switch to echo'ing that a service failed to start and pipe that through
tee so that we can keep the old behavior of touching a file (note this
behavior is slightly modified and the touched file will now have
contents).

Change-Id: I2d3f272b9a65a9d64dbbc01373a02fccf52f56a8
"}]
commit_message:
Echo service start failures.

* functions: Previously screen_it would log service start failures by
touching a file, this isn't very useful when working with Jenkins.
Switch to echo'ing that a service failed to start and pipe that through
tee so that we can keep the old behavior of touching a file (note this
behavior is slightly modified and the touched file will now have
contents).

Change-Id: I2d3f272b9a65a9d64dbbc01373a02fccf52f56a8

why not just change 
        stats = self.get_host_stats(refresh=True)
to 
        stats = self.get_host_stats(refresh=False)

in nova/virt/driver.py:1018 (get_available_nodes)


As the host_stats object is periodically refreshed anyway?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-08-09 01:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hm, yeah, I see get_host_stats() is updated in the _report_driver_status() periodic task.  I guess I could do that.  Just need to deal with the race where we need the nodes and the periodic task hasn't fired yet... as the virt driver methods would just return {} right now.  That's easy to fix, though.

The other issue is that we probably want available nodes refreshed in certain conditions... but I could add a 'refresh' argument to the get_available_nodes() driver call to solve that, also.

I'll make these changes and push them up and see how that looks."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-08-09 01:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

commit_message:
Improve performance of driver's get_available_nodes

get_available_nodes() is called every time an instance is updated.  That
ends up calling get_host_stats(refresh=True), resulting in a
libvirt/XenAPI/etc call.  On a build of a new instance when the instance
record is updated often (task_state and progress), this results in a lot
of unnecessary driver calls.

This changes get_available_nodes() to take a refresh kwarg to pass
through to get_host_stats(), defaulting to False so that it uses
the cache.  Places that used get_available_nodes() and are sensitive to
stale data are changed to add refresh=True.  Also adds a helper driver
method for 'is_node_available'.  And make sure that even if drivers'
get_host_stats() methods get refresh=False that they refresh when they
have no stats.

Fixes bug 1210264

Change-Id: I22c8d70e3e70f2d2421915da66c2618688e0db2b

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-07-09 06:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How interesting!

Seems to have been added in:

26ad9a4 Reduce transactions where possible with reclamations

But I see no explanation of why DatabaseBroker.reclaim remained, or why it's safe to unconditionally commit in the face of metadata reclaim errors.  gholt?

Either way the tests seemed to assert some specific behavior WRT metadata reclimation.  Even if the concrete classes call the base class method; their tests don't perform the same validations on the behavior near as I can tell.  I hate to loose good asserts.  Maybe you can fork lift the test code into the account and container broker test cases?

It doesn't really matter, but it would make more sense *to me* if the common code was implemented in the public method on base class which called into a private method for the divergent code - "_reclaim" would be a noop on the base class and then implement the specific table named deletes in the concerte classes.

basically on DatabaseBroker:

    def reclaim(self, resource_timestamp, sync_timestamp):
        self._commit_puts()
        with self.get() as conn:
            # delete old rows
            self._reclaim(conn, resource_timestamp)
            ... # clean up _sync tables
         ... # reclaim metadata
         conn.commit()

    def _reclaim(self, conn, resource_timestamp):
         """Implement removal of outdated deleted rows""" 
         pass

and on the ContainerBroker there'd be no override of `reclaim`; just a working definition for `_relcaim`

    def _reclaim(self, conn, object_timestamp):
        return conn.execute('''
                       ....
                   ''', (object_timestamp,))'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-07-10 15:08:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Clay, please reconsider from the standpoint of the LFS effort where we're documenting the API. If the common code in the base class invokes methods of derived classes, they cannot be declared private and remain in API. If this is not in the base class, the only way is name it reclaim_implement or other public name.

In any case, I don't want to go that far and mix improvements with a removal of provably unused code. Maybe we don't do a lot of git bisect, but we should split up things like that, and do not mix up."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-07-10 15:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Pete, don't get me wrong buddy!  I'm totally neutral on the patch as it stands.

+1 get rid of un-used code
-1 get rid of good asserts

The asserts seem to be on the behavior of the base class method _reclaim (shared code executed by the concerte classes).  The *test* was using the "unused" reclaim method as an entry point to assert the behavior of the shared common code path.  Wasn't it?

As far as the refactor, or the questionable behavior change that slipped in the orignal patch... yeah that's all separate to this fix.  I just found it interesting that we had dead code laying around, normally indicates something strange.  Sorry if you find it distracting here... :\

But if we're on the subject of defining an interface; the reclaim method would be the public interface; no doubt.  But just for the sake of DRY it seems totally reasonable to put shared code in a common parent class, and there _reclaim could certainly be marked as "should be implemented in subclasses".  Lots of "drivers" in nova and cinder do basically this; and that more or less mostly works for them.

A new implementation may not share *any* code with DatabaseBrokers' reclaim method, and if it overrides it, it may not need to define a _reclaim.  I might not understand your concern.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-07-19 02:24:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If you compare the two reclaim methods in the account and container broker subclasses it looks like one could refactor them to properly rely on the super class by passing the SQL statement.

Could you try that?"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-07-24 01:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-24 02:22:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-07-09 05:31:12.000000000', 'message': "Eliminate DatabaseBroker.reclaim

Since both AccountBroker and ContainerBroker install their own reclaim
methods, the method in the parent class appears to be unused. Note in
particular that it has a different number of arguments.

Of course, external code in Python may import just about anything,
but it's very hard to imagine anyone trying to use DatabaseBroker.

Change-Id: Ic5e38a9e39dafe8e0bc062818151edece384f3b5
"}, {'created': '2013-07-24 01:35:28.000000000', 'message': 'Unify DatabaseBroker.reclaim

Both AccountBroker and ContainerBroker install their own reclaim()
methods, which are the same modulo the table and column names.
Also, the parent reclaim() method is unused, except as a tramptoline
to test _reclaim().

This patch gets rid of the unused code by moving into the tests,
and unifies the reclaim() method in DatabaseBroker. We use the
same class parameters that are already in use elsewhere.

The unused code was found when documenting the DB broker API for
the LFS. The unification fell out of reviews by Clay and Peter.

Change-Id: Ic5e38a9e39dafe8e0bc062818151edece384f3b5

commit_message:
Unify DatabaseBroker.reclaim

Both AccountBroker and ContainerBroker install their own reclaim()
methods, which are the same, modulo the table and column names.
Also, the parent reclaim() method is unused, except as a tramptoline
to test _reclaim().

This patch gets rid of the unused code by moving it into the tests,
and unifies the reclaim() method in DatabaseBroker. We use the
same class parameters that are already in use elsewhere.

The unused code was found when documenting the DB broker API for
the LFS. The unification fell out of reviews by Clay and Peter.

Change-Id: Ic5e38a9e39dafe8e0bc062818151edece384f3b5

only tests the manager side.  It also removes testing of
scheduler_utils's set_vm_state_and_notify method as that is already
tested separately.

Change-Id: I30bd3897311870b10c8ec65182c81d341a904485
"}, {'created': '2013-08-16 23:36:46.000000000', 'message': "Fixup some non-unity-ness to conductor tests

This moves some conductor compute task tests into the test class that
only tests the manager side.  It also removes testing of
scheduler_utils's set_vm_state_and_notify method as that is already

Change-Id: I30bd3897311870b10c8ec65182c81d341a904485

commit_message:
Fixup some non-unity-ness to conductor tests

This moves some conductor compute task tests into the test class that
only tests the manager side.  It also removes testing of
scheduler_utils's set_vm_state_and_notify method as that is already
tested separately.

Change-Id: I30bd3897311870b10c8ec65182c81d341a904485

commit_message:
Convert admin_actions ext tests to unit tests

The tests for the admin_actions API extension (or v3 plugin) are
stubbing out conductor methods, which creates a lot of pain when
compute_api internals are changed.  Convert these tests to unit tests,
checking only that the appropriate compute_api methods are called with
the correct arguments.

Change-Id: I16634efa2397b36afa15b90712bfd678325bc049

commit_message:
Unit-ify the compute API resize tests

Move resize related compute API tests to test_compute_api and make them
unit tests.  This makes test changes easier when converting to objects.

This also caught a couple things where the cells compute api class was
not in sync that don't really end up being bugs, but need to match for
tests to pass.

Change-Id: I194310beb5e821e4a8262310d1bb80e0747e1c43

commit_message:
Refactor LVM driver to use Brick VG utility

Refactor the LVM driver to utilize bricks LVM
module.  This includes significant modification to
tests and fake objects related to testing.

implements blueprint: refactor-lvm-and-iscsi-driver

Change-Id: I94e41abf90d0c5b77e732d40ed8b81b0a2f5d7dd

Now that compute/api.py:update() is no longer being called for instance
updates the policy check is no longer enforced.  This adds policy
checking back in at the API level so that the compute:update policy will
continue to function as it did before.

Bug 1212807

Change-Id: I365ad8ac2845d914deefb841c314a50f4869dba0
'}]
commit_message:
Enforce compute:update policy in API

Now that compute/api.py:update() is no longer being called for instance
updates the policy check is no longer enforced.  This adds policy
checking back in at the API level so that the compute:update policy will
continue to function as it did before.

Bug 1212807

Change-Id: I365ad8ac2845d914deefb841c314a50f4869dba0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-16 21:20:42.000000000', 'message': 'Some how DELETE not using _parse_path()

It seems as this conversion was missed, as a git blame says the first
few lines of DELETE date all the way back to commit 001407b9 "(creiht)
2010-07-12 Initial commit of Swift code".

While we were in here, we moved _parse_path() to a module method as
there appears to be need to keep it as an object controller method.

We also fixed up as many of the tests that directly invoked the object
controller methods to use get_response(), addressing a few
inconsistencies along the way.

Change-Id: If491c7129d61d6fc7d81401fbc3650c29ed80465
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Some how DELETE not using _parse_path()

It seems as this conversion was missed, as a git blame says the first
few lines of DELETE date all the way back to commit 001407b9 "(creiht)
2010-07-12 Initial commit of Swift code".

While we were in here, we moved _parse_path() to a module method as
there appears to be need to keep it as an object controller method.

We also fixed up as many of the tests that directly invoked the object
controller methods to use get_response(), addressing a few
inconsistencies along the way.

Change-Id: If491c7129d61d6fc7d81401fbc3650c29ed80465
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fixes SSH injection threat in 3PAR driver

The setqos ssh command was not built up correctly when the following
patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37697/ landed for cleaning up
the SSH calls from injection attacks in the 3PAR driver.

The command was in the following format causing the injection threat
due to the spaces in the second item in the list:
['setqos', '-io 5000 -bw 500M vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']
When it should actually be in the following format:
['setqos', '-io', '5000', '-bw', '500M', 'vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']

This patch fixes an append vs. extend that was introduced in patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42241

Also fixes: bug 1212884

Change-Id: I28f84acd02397ee0d433a666375737145904d67e

Yeah perfect this is just what https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32808/ needs.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-28 10:55:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I agree that filtering in Swift core makes sense. 

It also makes sense to filter as a service to the middleware (i.e. filter headers based on the middleware that is being used)

But the mechanism need to be more dynamic in two respects:

1. It needs to allow finer grain filtering (filter where and in what case)

2. The filter should really be dynamically created and not come from a config file - this way we can filter based on state and avoid the need to have the deployer make all those config mistakes of leaving out a filter when he added a new middleware to the pipeline and opening his system to a security threat he did not consider.

See comments."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-28 14:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sounds okay. If that's what everybody wants to do I can wait for that and abandon this change no problem (as I'm fond of saying, "I've thrown away much more code than I've kept.").'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-28 16:17:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My previous review was done before I though of generalizing the problem and trying to solve it with controller_callbacks. 

If we introduce conroller_callbacks, than this remove the need for dynamically setting filters - since we allow middleware to implement its own filter at the callback. 

Still there may be room for adding a config parameter that will state which headers should be used as suggested here in case pepole see a need to control the filter with config param. 

I would still expect middleware to be self contained and not rely on the poor admin remembering to also set the proper filter. 

So really my only issue with this patch is the 'x-account-meta-temp-url-key, x-account-meta-temp-url-key-2' that should not be there in the server.py and in the etc/proxy-server.conf-sample."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-06-28 17:08:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Please do not abandon this change.  That is certainly NOT what I want to do.

I think most of David's comments are skewed by an assumption that the Account-ACL [1] and everything in it currently is close to merging.  IMHO that branch has really grown some horns in the last few patch sets and I'm hoping he can reign it back in.

In the meantime, I'll encourage other reviewers to evaluate this patch as it stands: a flexible solution to an existing problem that is self contained and well tested.

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32808/"}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-28 23:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

At this point in time this looks better to have it than not having it (we may still want to get the tempurl key headers out of swift core - but we can leave it to future).'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-06-29 00:12:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> we may still want to get the tempurl key headers out of swift core

Or the opposite!  According to:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Swift/API#Features_in_Swift_v1_API

There's strong support for finding a sane way to promote tempurl as a core part of the Swift API !?

But you're right, unrelated to this change..."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-08-12 19:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-12 19:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

- http://logs.openstack.org/38/34738/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/3d208c1 : SUCCESS in 17m 32s

- http://logs.openstack.org/38/34738/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5427def : SUCCESS in 21m 07s
'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-08-15 18:52:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I keep waffling on this one.

On the one hand, it seems like tempurl ought to be responsible for its own headers.

On the other hand, what if tempurl comes before your other auth system in the pipeline? That config should work, but then tempurl doesn't know if swift_owner will be set or not, so it can't really do much. I guess it could look at the request environment after it calls self.app(), but that's awfully fragile.

But then, what if you're running a system without any auth at all, and it's just wide open? Then you can't ever see your ACLs or tempurl keys... but then, would you run tempurl at all in such a system? Why bother? And who cares about ACLs when there's no access control?

This change may be too much for my feeble brain to comprehend. I dunno."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-15 19:57:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sam, EVERYONE

It's not about tempurl or acls' - it's about x-container-meta-quota-bytes, or even some *other* random middleware that didn't consider if it's metadata should be leaked across shared swift resources (or if a deployer might not *want* that even if you think it's fine to share).  Sure tempurl should clean up it's own headers, container-quota's too (probably?), and neither of them should be using x-blah-*meta* because that should be a user only namespace that core features shouldn't be conflicting with, but that's neither here nor there.

IMHO, for now, until we can figure this out, we should put a flexible solution in the hands operator.  Even once we figure out how to remove some of these core metadata from the list and handle them with a better solution - I think an escape hatch for the operator is still a quite useful option to expose."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-08-15 23:05:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Alright, I'm convinced. Thanks, Clay.

The only thing I'd do is call h.pop(key) instead of "if key in h: del h[key]", but that's getting awfully bikesheddy even for me.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-15 23:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-27 14:11:46.000000000', 'message': "Implements configurable swift_owner_headers

These are headers that will be stripped unless the WSGI environment
contains a true value for 'swift_owner'. The exact definition of a
swift_owner is up to the auth system in use, but usually indicates
administrative responsibilities.

Note that this may get included in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32808/ in which case this change can
be abandoned. But, in case that change takes another couple of weeks
or longer I thought it important to at least get this change in
sooner.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I972772fbbd235414e00130ca663428e8750cabca

contains a true value for 'swift_owner'. The exact definition of a
swift_owner is up to the auth system in use, but usually indicates
administrative responsibilities.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I972772fbbd235414e00130ca663428e8750cabca
"}]
commit_message:
Implements configurable swift_owner_headers

These are headers that will be stripped unless the WSGI environment
contains a true value for 'swift_owner'. The exact definition of a
swift_owner is up to the auth system in use, but usually indicates
administrative responsibilities.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I972772fbbd235414e00130ca663428e8750cabca

commit_message:
Fix LDAP Identity get user with user_enabled_mask

Fetching users using the LDAP Identity backend would fail with

 KeyError: 'enabled'

from _ldap_res_to_model when user_enabled_mask is not 0.

Change-Id: I39a9606ba7210f0fea064abd6adad379218b432b
Closes-Bug: #1210175

subject: Fix LDAP Identity with non-zero user_enabled_default

commit_message:
Fix LDAP Identity with non-zero user_enabled_default

The LDAP Identity backend was not properly using the
user_enabled_default option as a string. This caused
operations to fail with

 TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for &: 'str' and 'int'

Partial-Bug: #1210175

Change-Id: I54931e669186871d18dea088870945b9de40d573

commit_message:
Implement missing Coraid Driver functionality for Havana

Intorduce a brick connector for AoE protocol.
Refactoring Coraid Driver. Implement missing functionality for Havana:
- Copy Volume To Image
- Copy Image To Volume
- Clone Volume

Fix a bug with resize volume command.

Change-Id: I2af6a41dc44cb8bc4b74da752e0be9ed54a83cb1
Implements: blueprint coraid-driver-refactoring-for-havana

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-09 15:49:18.000000000', 'message': "Add necessary v3 parts to boot a VM

This is very WIP right now, since there are no tests and some of
this will probably be split into separate commits, but with these
changes I was able to boot a VM using the v3 API so I thought it
might be useful to get it out there for people to see.

It would obviously be possible to refactor the images extension
to reduce a lot of the code duplication between versions, but I'm
unsure how much I should be messing with the existing 1_1 code.
Comments welcome.

bp v3-api

Change-Id: I252a9c4ecc6696fa50b009b7195844a41c51da11
"}, {'created': '2013-08-14 03:00:39.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Add necessary v3 parts to boot a VM

Still very WIP, but this time using Glance for image operations
instead of the outgoing os-images extension.  Again, these
changes were sufficient to boot a VM, but a lot more testing and
cleanup work is needed.

Note: This will fail Jenkins because some of the requests to Nova
had to change.  I'm not going to update the test cases until I'm
more certain this is the right approach.

bp v3-api

Change-Id: I252a9c4ecc6696fa50b009b7195844a41c51da11
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Add necessary v3 parts to boot a VM

Still very WIP, but this time using Glance for image operations
instead of the outgoing os-images extension.  Again, these
changes were sufficient to boot a VM, but a lot more testing and
cleanup work is needed.

Note: This will fail Jenkins because some of the requests to Nova
had to change.  I'm not going to update the test cases until I'm
more certain this is the right approach.

bp v3-api

Change-Id: I252a9c4ecc6696fa50b009b7195844a41c51da11

commit_message:
More validation in test_user_enable_attribute_mask

Validate the enabled attribute returned by create_user, update_user.
Also, validate that the enabled attribute in the LDAP server is
set.

Change-Id: I78d194528ad4fd67fc35ca4d124f2e031d02d9cc
Related-Bug: #1210175

commit_message:
scheduler options and block storage admin link fixed

reference bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1212862 for the final solution to the two scheduler pages under config and compute admin being out of synch. Both these pages no longer have references to the compute volume scheduler and a now have a link to the block storage admin guide

bug 1193432
Change-Id: I1daf2f3469eb64d90ebd2a5f286508da21167b70

checking to see if code work. also working on patch for oslo -- for some reason it doesn't like that pycadf library uses oslo.config to load cadf config file... gives me:

    cfg_file = cfg.CONF.find_file(CONF.audit.api_audit_map)
  File "/opt/stack/oslo-incubator/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo/config/cfg.py", line 1866, in find_file
    if self.config_dir:
  File "/opt/stack/oslo-incubator/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo/config/cfg.py", line 1606, in __getattr__
    return self._get(name)
  File "/opt/stack/oslo-incubator/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo/config/cfg.py", line 1930, in _get
    value = self._substitute(self._do_get(name, group, namespace))
  File "/opt/stack/oslo-incubator/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo/config/cfg.py", line 1948, in _do_get
    info = self._get_opt_info(name, group)
  File "/opt/stack/oslo-incubator/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo/config/cfg.py", line 2029, in _get_opt_info
    raise NoSuchOptError(opt_name, group)
NoSuchOptError: no such option: config_dir'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:39:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Usually that's a sign you didn't called cfg.CONF()"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-15 14:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

strip spaces before writing the files

Without stripping the spaces tools/validate.py will not accept
the generated XML files.

Change-Id: I67d58cdf602107be05c6152eb59e4c12a2c0afd4

subject: Change whitespace check to be info only
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-13 09:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/23/41623/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-validate/fbc7c1d : SUCCESS in 26m 55s
'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-13 13:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why do you want to allow unnecessary spaces? The methods only checks for really unnecessary spaces (trailing spaces like "</foobar>     ") or for spaces after opening elements and before closing elements (like "<foobar>   Some text" or "Some text     </foobar>") (only checking for defined elements). I think we don't need those spaces inside the documents. In my opinion (that's why I implemented this method) the validation should fail when using unnecessary spaces.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-08-13 13:18:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's causing new contributors pain to the point where they're very frustrated or even angry."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-13 13:24:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's usual to run a strict validation inside the other OpenStack projects (using flake8). Why should we not introduce a strict validation for the XML sources of the documents?

At the moment nearly all documents are looking different, are using different highlights, have broken program listings, have different indentations...

And I don't understand why new contributors are angry or frustrated because of some failed validations."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-08-13 19:14:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A couple of comments and thoughts. 

Doc contributors are not accustomed to checking for whitespace, because the output is the same either way. I know it makes the diffs harder to read, but they already are difficult to read. 

I haven't gotten frustrated input yet so Tom you should probably make sure more of us know about that.

I was a bit taken aback yesterday when I was rebasing someone else's patch to merge, and the gate had changed in the mean time, so I had to clean up spaces that were not whitespace problems, such as a space after <title> or before </title>. I'd like the scripts to take over whitespace clean up prior to the gate. For example, I thought if I just ran validate.py against a single file, it would clean up the white space. My tests didn't show that to be true (or maybe I'm just doing it wrong?) 

Overall, these seem like good clean up to me and the frustration will occur during this time of many markup changes. Once we get cleaner source it should be better for new contributors. 

That said, we have a lot of content, over 30 books, so is there more value in whitespace cleanup or doc bug fixing? I know which way I lean on that one. 

So let's try a softer start so we can get people used to it. Sound good?"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-14 05:06:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Anne, I think it's not a good idea to automatically change something in the documents on the gates.

I could provide scripts for tools/ to automatically remove the spaces. Then we can change the whitespace check in tools/validate.py to be informal only and run the scripts regular to cleanup the documents."}, {'account_id': 6772, 'date': '2013-08-14 11:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"At the moment nearly all documents are looking different, are using different highlights, have broken program listings, have different indentations..."

The updated validation isn't checking for any of those things though, it's checking for trailing whitespace that has no discernible impact on the rendered output at all.'}, {'account_id': 6772, 'date': '2013-08-14 11:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-14 12:04:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

It's just an entry point to not allow trailing white spaces and unnecessary spaces. Sure, the validation has to be extended in the future. When only printing informal notes nobody will take care of them. Changing my score to 0. If the majority prefers to only have informal notes that's okay for me."}, {'account_id': 7264, 'date': '2013-08-14 23:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Makes good sense.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-15 09:52:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I added two scripts to manually cleanup spaces at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42092/.

Maybe it's possible to create a job on Jenkins to run those scripts before the commit to automatically cleanup the files."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-15 09:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

While there are now scripts available for everybody to remove the spaces found with the introduced validation method I think there is no more problem to apply this patch.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-08-15 11:10:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm actually thinking again about this patch.

I think a better way to alter this might be to separate the whitespace from the validate, so that when jenkins posts a message it comes on two separate lines eg
XML Validation (Success)
Whitespace Check (FAIL - please run tools/cleanup/remove_trailing_whitespaces.sh, check the result and resubmit using git commit -a --amend && git review)

This way it would ensure our whitespaces are always pristine, and it gives people clear, simple instructions on how to fix the failure problem ... potentially also without digging in deep log files ...

Not sure how possible it is - would welcome thoughts!"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-08-15 12:48:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think that's possible using a non-voting Jenkins job. I can separate the validation method and add some parameters to specify what the script should do. Than we can setup a new job on Jenkins.

I think we should have three jobs:

  * Is the syntax valid? (voting)
  * Is building of all affected books possible? (voting)
  * Are there any other rules hurt (like the trailing whitespaces)? (non-voting)

Have a look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38762/ for several Jenkins jobs. For the other projects it's usual to have (for example) a validation job, some devstack jobs, some python jobs."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-08-15 14:09:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I like the idea of categories of jobs - 
Do individual files validate? We need to have olinks working for this to ever happen.
Do all the books build? If not which ones are problematic and why?
Are we being careful about whitespace? If not which ones are failing the whitespace tests?

I think that we need the "Failed" messages about images to be fixed in the build tool in order to make these logs more useful. I've talked to David Cramer about this and will continue to nudge. 

In the meantime, let's make whitespace non-voting.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-08-16 20:08:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Let's do this."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-16 20:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-16 20:40:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/23/41623/1/gate/gate-openstack-manuals-validate/fcabc15 : SUCCESS in 10m 48s
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-16 20:40:57.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-13 08:33:47.000000000', 'message': 'Change whitespace check to be info only

The recent introduction of the whitespace check has been good for
improving our consistency, however while discussion is ongoing
about how to best manage whitespace, the check should be non-voting.

This patch (intended to be temporary while discussion continues)
changes the script to print when whitespace is wrong,
rather than leaving a -1 vote.

Change-Id: I082aa4418864cd50d087dfe01c3bfff4d6df9f8f
'}]
commit_message:
Change whitespace check to be info only

The recent introduction of the whitespace check has been good for
improving our consistency, however while discussion is ongoing
about how to best manage whitespace, the check should be non-voting.

This patch (intended to be temporary while discussion continues)
changes the script to print when whitespace is wrong,
rather than leaving a -1 vote.

Change-Id: I082aa4418864cd50d087dfe01c3bfff4d6df9f8f

commit_message:
\Allow removal of properties using glance v2 api

This adds support to the glance client library for removing
properties from an image. Properties to be removed must be
explicitly listed. There is no equivalent of the 'purge_props'
functionality in v1.

Also beefed up testing around create since some of the
functionality is the same as update.

Fixes bug 1206472

Change-Id: I16f4c39cdfc8a0cd07bede600461b7a289fbb080

commit_message:
Staticweb shortcut object 404s

Right now static web checks to see if it should handle a
request and if it decides that it shouldn't, in all cases,
it lets the request pass through the pipeline normally.
After this change on "x-web-mode: t" obj requests where
staticweb is not setup and an object 404s it will just
return the 404 instead of letting the app send a duplicate
request to the object servers.

Change-Id: I824f4b03f7546d26084fd51b97ea6e290169d22a

commit_message:
Revert "Refactor configuring of floating ips on a router."

This patch breaks gating job.
Because nat rule for metadata will be only added on the
router_add.
Revert it for now.

Fixes bug 1211829
This reverts commit 9382ee659212285a203550cf60476dd146d27a29.

Change-Id: I05925798cddc7a706e922025ef6ce27b6638ffb6

'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-30 11:16:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

While I'm happy with the DB changed, how we associate volume types and feature like QoS or encryption is currently under discussion. I'd rather get that ironed out first since there doesn't seem to be anything that uses this code yet (further volume encryption patches can be based off this review just fine)

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/cinder-volume-types-evolution and recent cinder meeting logs for discussion"}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-31 19:05:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Will follow up on the QOS thread .. but we would very much like this to have this patch merged in to provide true random encryption keys early in the Havana release cycle so that encrypted volumes as a feature can mature. 

Given that the QOS issue is resolved ..
But given that Key Manager is an incubation project, how should be handle this key manager integration in the interim?"}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-31 22:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just took a look at the etherpad mentioned. My take: a volume is encrypted or not. QOS and paying extra for super fast volume access is a layer above this. 

For instance, if one encrypted a string on a low power, software only solution machine and generated an encrypted string foo. Had one done the same on a hardware supported machine, the same foo would be generated faster.
To decrypt foo, either machine types would work.

To provide a certain level of QOS, service level aggreement,  only some devices may qualify to support the volume.
But given that dmcrypt runs on all linux installs, and down the road a heterogenous environment of compute hosts, there may exist a windows/mac version that provides equivalent functionality, only the encryption driver may change.

Will snip the above thoughts to the etherpad for discussion.'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-06-05 09:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Keeping the discussion all together:

All the statements regarding LUKS are correct as is your comment about LUKS needing a high-quality source of entropy to generate the master key. I dont believe that the LUKS extensions to cryptsetup allow the master key to be specified by the user; regular cryptsetup must be used instead.

Using LUKS is convenient for an initial implementation for volume encryption because it stores encryption metadata (e.g., the cipher) on disk whereas using regular cryptsetup requires this metadata to be stored elsewhere (i.e., the Cinder database). An incremental addition to our current implementation would be support for regular cryptsetup, which we may pursue at some point in the future.

Cheers,
Joel

-----Original Message-----
From: Bhandaru, Malini K [mailto:malini.k.bhandaru@intel.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, June 04, 2013 3:42 AM
To: Coffman, Joel M.; cloudkeep@googlegroups.com
Cc: Robert Esker; John Griffith; Ben Swartzlander; Aaron Rosen; Genin, Daniel I.; Bryan D. Payne <bdpayne@acm.org> (bdpayne@acm.org)
Subject: RE: Change in openstack/nova[master]: Add encryption support for volumes

Thank you Joel for the LUKS references. Am I correct in understanding that the LUKS will generate a master key on its own to encrypt the block data and the passphrase provided is just to encrypt the master key? Upto 8 such passphrases may be provided and to protext the passphrases they are hashed multiple times, xored (PBKDF2) is to make human friendly passphrases harder to crack, which may not be necessary with a key manager generated passphrase, but that is just extra protection, no harm.

If LUKS is generating the master-key, it needs a high quality entropy source.  With compute nodes chiefly hosting VMs, no keyboard/mouse etc .. they may not have as rich an entropy source as possibly the key manager machine, which being fewer in number may have a I/O devices, hardware random number generators etc.

Just wanted to bring the above up.
Regards
Malini



-----Original Message-----
From: Joel Coffman (Code Review) [mailto:review@openstack.org] 
Sent: Monday, June 03, 2013 8:35 AM
Cc: Robert Esker; John Griffith; Ben Swartzlander; Aaron Rosen; Bhandaru, Malini K; Dan Genin
Subject: Change in openstack/nova[master]: Add encryption support for volumes

Joel Coffman has posted comments on this change.

Change subject: Add encryption support for volumes ......................................................................


Patch Set 2:

Our current implementation uses LUKS, which stores a hash of the passphrase on disk. Regular dm-crypt without using LUKS has no way to validate the passphrase so the volume will be mounted but decrypted incorrectly (i.e., the contents of the mounted volume should look like random bytes).

More details regarding LUKS are available in the following two papers:
1) TKS1 - An anti-forensic, two level, and iterated key setup scheme [http://clemens.endorphin.org/TKS1-draft.pdf] and
2) LUKS On-Disk Format Speci?cation
Version 1.2.1 [http://wiki.cryptsetup.googlecode.com/git/LUKS-standard/on-disk-format.pdf].'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-06-05 09:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Joel for the LUKs references. Now I see why it is not necessary to save the encryption algorithm and related data in Cinder thanks to LUKS saving it in a platform independent way on the disk after encrypting. I meant some document describing what will go into Nova, Cinder, other projects?  What will you use for key management, etc.  The big picture :)'}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-07-23 21:17:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The specification contains the most complete overview (see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VolumeEncryption#System_Architecture) although I'll try to fill in a few additional details that pertain specifically to the issues you mentioned.

Our initial implementation relies on Nova to perform the encryption (proposed change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30976/). One advantage to this approach is that it can be used for any storage backend, including those that don't offer encryption built-in. Another more important advantage is that the iSCSI traffic between the compute host and storage host is encrypted. Nevertheless, our architecture should allow similar support to be implemented entirely within Cinder (i.e., we aren't trying to preclude support for storage backends that already offer encryption).

Key management is probably the biggest question that arises with this work. We've proposed a key manager interface (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30973/) to abstract interacting with Barbican, a KMIP server, etc. That interaction is out of scope for our immediate work: we don't particularly care how the key server is implemented as long as we can create and retrieve keys from it. (Using the encryption feature with an insecure key server wouldn't be advisable, but again, we deem key management to be an orthogonal problem.) I expect us to copy the existing key manager interface that was accepted by Nova into Cinder, and the eventual goal is to have the interface incubated in Oslo.

Cinder is responsible for the bookkeeping data necessary to support volume encryption -- namely, storing an encryption key UUID with each volume. It is also logical to reuse Cinder's volume type abstraction to denote encrypted volumes via the volume type. Accessing this information from Nova requires Cinder API extensions (part of this patch) and changes to python-cinderclient, which is currently in progress (we haven't submitted this code yet)."}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-07-30 14:45:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-30 15:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-08-14 12:11:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I've identified an issue with the current implementation that could render encrypted volumes inaccessible depending on which "encryption provider" (e.g., raw cryptsetup or LUKS) they use. To make a long story short, encryption schemes like raw cryptsetup require the metadata (e.g., the cipher and key size) each time a volume is mounted, and if the metadata changes, a volume encrypted with different parameters would no longer be accessible. (LUKS is immune to such changes because it copies the metadata into its header when the volume is formatted.) Hence, supporting update with the volume type encryption API extension is unsafe.

I'll post an updated version of this patch set that removes support for updating encryption metadata shortly, but I didn't want the existing patch set to be approved in the interim.'}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-08-14 12:15:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-14 13:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 00:03:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add encryption metadata to volume table

This modification adds an encryption key UUID field to the volume table, which
is sufficient to make Cinder "aware" of encrypted volumes as designated by
predefined volume types. Integration with a key manager is necessary to obtain
an actual encryption key UUID (the current implementation generates a random
UUID when an encrypted volumes is created). Cinder should *not* presume that it
necessarily will have access to the key itself -- this decision depends upon the
design, implementation, and policy for encrypted volumes. The key's UUID is
stored in Cinder because it is metadata about the volume.

Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes
Change-Id: I164290e761a9922919a70f22f99af70dac213b61
SecurityImpact

commit_message:
Add support for encrypted volumes

This modification adds an encryption key UUID field to the volume
table, which is sufficient to make Cinder "aware" of encrypted volumes
as designated by predefined volume types. Integration with a key
manager is necessary to obtain an actual encryption key UUID (the
current implementation generates a random UUID when an encrypted
volumes is created). Cinder should *not* presume that it necessarily
will have access to the key itself -- this decision depends upon the
design, implementation, and policy for encrypted volumes. The key's
UUID is stored in Cinder because it is metadata about the volume.

Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes
Change-Id: I164290e761a9922919a70f22f99af70dac213b61
SecurityImpact

commit_message:
Set launch_index to right value

Fix bug 1212648

When boot multiple instances in one request, the launch_index
was not increased.

The fix was increase the launch_index one by one for each instances
in one request.

Change-Id: I27dde8cfae52853d33277c3d8e0e65c91bc6280b

commit_message:
Returns 503 if the NVP cluster is in maintenance mode

If the NVP cluster is in 'readonly-mode' during a maintenance
window, some NVP operations may raise a Forbidden error. This
is not currently handled correctly, and Neutron server ends up
returning 500. This patch addresses the problem by ensuring
the right error code is returned.

Fixes bug 1204715

Change-Id: Ibd2cac8286a0978a95f9006142c2a405053dfa00

[{'created': '2013-08-09 00:03:46.000000000', 'message': 'Handle nvp default l3 gw service misconfiguration appropriately

Bug 1185885

Avoid returning an unrelated, backend-specific, error message to
the user, and ensure the logical router is removed from the
NVP backend.

Change-Id: I5f7b88480dab80a2138486e612e144b971691cf5
'}]
commit_message:
Handle nvp default l3 gw service misconfiguration appropriately

Bug 1185885

Avoid returning an unrelated, backend-specific, error message to
the user, and ensure the logical router is removed from the
NVP backend.

Change-Id: I5f7b88480dab80a2138486e612e144b971691cf5

commit_message:
Hadoop test can turn on and turn off

* Hadoop test for "Vanilla" plugin can turn on and turn off;
* Hadoop test for "HDP" plugin can turn on and turn off.

So I understand that it doesn't make sense for this to be in an incubating status, but I'm a little uncomfortable with the fact that the end result of removing this is a bunch of copy-pasted base exception code in all of the projects.  Is there/should there be a place to put common code that we don't necessarily want to be a separate library?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-08-05 10:17:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Most project should define their own exception based on their API and the context they evolve in. Many projects don't use this, only neutron and cinder used it. I've copy pasted the few exceptions that they were using, but that's still by far less code than this whole file.

Ultimately that will let them a chance to remove or shring their own exception.py. I don't think most projects should have one anyway."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-08-05 15:56:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for doing this Julien, I should have done it a long time ago

I agree with Joe in http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-August/013370.html that the commit message should contain a lot more "why" information.

It's not a problem for me with this patch, since I clearly understand the rationale here ... but when i see commit messages like this I get intensely frustrated ... "why is openstack.common.exception "obsolete"? Are you trying to tease me? Why couldn't you explain, even a little bit? Why? Why? Why?" :)

You end up explaining the rationale in the gerrit review anyway:

  Most project should define their own exception based on their API and the context they evolve in. Many projects don't use this, only neutron and cinder used it. I've copy pasted the few exceptions that they were using, but that's still by far less code than this whole file.

  Ultimately that will let them a chance to remove or shring their own exception.py. I don't think most projects should have one anyway.

commit_message:
exception: remove

This patch drops the obsolete openstack.common.exception module.

Most project should define their own exception based on their API and
the context they evolve in. Many projects don't use this, only neutron,
cinder and heat used it. I've copy pasted the few exceptions that they
were using, but that's still by far less code than this whole file.
Ultimately that will let them a chance to remove or shring their own
exception.py. I don't think most projects should have one anyway.

Change-Id: Ia8b2b29bd443233def324e97de7342c2634bccff
Closes-Bug: #1208734

[{'created': '2013-08-15 14:47:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix server list filtered by tenant_id.

The server list filtered by tenant_id is not working because the search
option passed in the request indicating the tenant_id is overwritten by
the users's project_id.
At the API layer we force some filters (like the project_id), that fix checks
that when we are doing the mapping "search_option_to_filter_name"
there are no conflicts between the search options passed and the filters
which are forced in the API layer.

Fixes bug 1211702

Change-Id: Ie10372420c338b8fc8f5d6752f74ac90ddb6f16b

commit_message:
Fix server list filtered by tenant_id

The server list filtered by tenant_id is not working because the search
option passed in the request indicating the tenant_id is overwritten by
the users's project_id.
At the API layer we force some filters (like the project_id), that fix checks
that when we are doing the mapping "search_option_to_filter_name"
there are no conflicts between the search options passed and the filters
which are forced in the API layer.

Fixes bug 1211702

Change-Id: Ie10372420c338b8fc8f5d6752f74ac90ddb6f16b

subject: Remove deprecated CONF.fixed_range

commit_message:
Remove deprecated CONF.fixed_range

This was deprecated in Grizzly, and the TODO said remove for Havana.
fixed_range was deprecated in I4ec111079f7a1d253190e6a6008048f992a53f68

DocImpact: Remove deprecated config option

Change-Id: I1f429de7a7091adbd3a178d287b3a90e02664450

commit_message:
Cleanup: Add common "create_server" method

In scenario tests, there are many "create server" methods and their
behaviors are almost same. They creates a server with random name,
default image and default flavor, and waits for server status "ACTIVE".
So this patch adds a common "create_server" method and uses the method
instead of each implementation for code-cleanup.

Change-Id: I663cf1c994307160c9f0ebf51fa4c920f2b6125e

inline comments left. follow them in order of the numbers in them'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-08-13 03:15:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Does a MOVE apply across containers?

Does a MOVE apply across accounts?

Is a MOVE equivalent to a COPY followed by DELETE?"}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-13 05:38:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

John: Ok, I didn't realize you called the renamer() "local copy". You mark an interesting point since I didn't added a similar check to the get_data_file_size() of the GET. It will be add in the next update.

Peter: Indeed, the idea of this MOVE implementation is to have a most efficient way to move object than COPY + DELETE. Like COPY, it can copy across containers but not across accounts.'}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-13 06:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-13 06:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

What happens if the target node is different to the source device? 

For example, I used a test ring with 10 nodes in 10 zones. If I move an object on this ring, none of the original nodes is responsible for the new object. I could use the handoff nodes, but this will still result in data movement (though at a later point in time).'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-08-13 12:33:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

I don't think we can consider merging this until we have worked out the various state transitions that need to happen here."}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2013-08-13 12:42:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Another issue: using handoff nodes requires a lot of replication traffic after the MOVE request since the objects on the handoff nodes have to be moved to their final destination.

This might be a very easy way to DOS the whole cluster with a few MOVE operations."}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-13 16:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Clay: Ok, I will create one.'}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-15 20:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-08-15 20:32:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-15 21:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41581/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/e35eab0 : SUCCESS in 19m 39s
- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41581/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/390478c : SUCCESS in 44m 32s
- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41581/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/9c230e0 : SUCCESS in 21m 58s
'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-15 21:53:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Awesome, thanks for that - very helpful.

Ok, so then I do have some high-level questions:

Should the account be included in the X-Move-From (different from COPY)?
How will ACL authorization be enforced at the target location?
What if the new name hashes to a partition on a different node?

Maybe I don't understand the data flow:

For COPY

client -> PUT a/c/o2 {x-copy-from c/o} proxy
  proxy -> GET a/c/o storage1
    proxy <- a/c/o storage1 DATA
    proxy -> PUT a/c/o2 storage2 DATA
    proxy <- 2xx storage1
  proxy <- 2xx storage2
client <- 2xx client

Also, what's the use case?  Is it really equivalent to COPY + DELETE?  The commit message describes an implementation (a hard link?!) that sounds like it's fundamentally different than COPY + DELETE.  But if it is *equivalent* then whats the situation that the tiny little DELETE request at the end is problematic?  I don't think I'm against supporting MOVE as a nice to have, but it'd be easier to prioritize if there was put in the context of blocking support for a given use case.

^ please respond on the blue print whiteboard if possible"}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-15 22:28:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Clay: I added the current use case on the launchpad.

> Should the account be included in the X-Move-From (different from COPY)?
I copied the API design from the COPY, so for the moment I didn't planned it. Maybe it would be great to unify COPY and the potential MOVE.

> How will ACL authorization be enforced at the target location?
For the moment, the only authorization check is the build of the target location (and it's not really a check): the client provides c/o, and the proxy concatenates the account before: a/c/o. I guess additional checks will be required.

> What if the new name hashes to a partition on a different node?
It's my mind and it's not supported yet. Peter in the patch set 2 proposed a beginning of idea based on the ETags, but maybe it would generate too big changes..."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-08-15 23:01:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

>> What if the new name hashes to a partition on a different node?

> It's my mind and it's not supported yet.

I suspect this is what will ultimately doom this patch.

The probability that the first replica of the old object will end up on the same disk as the first replica of the new object is roughly 1/N, where N is the number of disks in the system (assuming equal weight, blah blah blah).

Now, with 3 replicas, the probability that all 3 replicas of the old object wind up sharing drives with replicas of the new object is somewhere around 3! / (N^3). The factorial is how many ways you can match up the three old replicas with the three new ones, as you don't have to match 1 --> 1, 2 --> 2, and 3 --> 3; you can match 1 --> 3, 2 --> 2, and 3 --> 1, for example.

Now, let's consider a very modest cluster with 50 disks (5 nodes, 10 disks per). Break out the REPL for some arithmetic, and we get...

    >>> 6.0 / (50 ** 3)
    4.8e-05

...which means that any particular MOVE command has a 0.0048% chance of working.

Scale that up to a medium-size cluster with, say, 20 nodes of 24 disks each, and it looks like this:

    >>> 6.0 * ((20*24) ** 3)
    5.4253472222222225e-08

Less than one in ten million. And it only worsens as the cluster grows."}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:05:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6723, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:08:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I mark this review as abandoned, I'll see later if I have new ideas."}]

commit_message:
Support of MOVE for objects

This patch allows clients to make MOVE HTTP requests on objects
(equivalent of COPY followed by DELETE). For an obvious reason of
performance, this action is handled directly by the storage node that
renames the object and sets the correct metas.
MOVE is processable across containers in a simalar way to COPY.

MOVE is implemented by combining the creation of a hard link on the
Object Server (LINK) and the delete of the old object (DELETE).

bp: swift-move

Change-Id: I1f39b17b1e3cf794a5bd3b9ff0b58b5a6e7eee91

commit_message:
Remove positive tag

The positive tag/type remained in tempest from the distant past,
every non negative test is positive, we do not need a positive tag.

The positive tags are removed in order to avoid future confusion.

Change-Id: I433dcee242186d1b5459d09b06b76b22a14c847d

commit_message:
Allow Ambari users to be specified in configuration

Ambari users and passwords can now be modified via standard or advanced templates

Fixes: bug #1208952
Change-Id: Iade795bac8b55b5bd68e2dadefbddcc7c3ad671b
(cherry picked from commit 842b93b554fd9f46044f0b2be981af011036d953)

commit_message:
Add a stub API method for updating a JobOrigin object

Update will raise a not implemented error. Fixed
existing unimplemented PUT methods in v10.py to take
"data" as an argument.

Change-Id: Ie2793aec33bc8fe2e71f66bf4302770ec9cb7fb7

commit_message:
Add nose to run_tests and tox for python 2.6

This commit adds python 2.6 to both tox and run_tests. 2 new tox jobs
are added py26-full and py26-smoke, which will use nose as the test
runner. run_tests.sh is also modified to detect whether python2.6 is
being used, and if so it will use nose instead of testr.

Change-Id: Ia7cecbea99ba2f995a726def6f775a313c4e94ba

commit_message:
Make Event object independent of resource object

The event table is pretty much self contained. So we actually don't
need to referece the corresponding resources to retrieve information.

Fixes bug #1204506

Change-Id: If0b88e0f9e243cf3cc6d747ffa04b9a429ea83a2

commit_message:
Fixed test for non-public flavor

1. Fixed test to check non-public flavor is available for
owner tenant but not for other tenants

2. Skipping this test until the fix for this bug is
committed in nova.

Change-Id: I9917915c098d0f74948331735f4ba6ae54c03896
Part of bug 1209101

[{'created': '2013-08-15 13:19:44.000000000', 'message': 'skip test_list_servers_filtered_by_ip_regex on neutron gate

The regexp based ip filtering is stalled in neutron and will not be
fixed soon. The test case will be disabled in the neutron runs until it
 is fixed.

A related review:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38600/

Change-Id: If1eb3e63289be7f5b560a7055b47769f8e1061fd
'}]
commit_message:
skip test_list_servers_filtered_by_ip_regex on neutron gate

The regexp based ip filtering is stalled in neutron and will not be
fixed soon. The test case will be disabled in the neutron runs until it
 is fixed.

A related review:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38600/

Change-Id: If1eb3e63289be7f5b560a7055b47769f8e1061fd

commit_message:
Unit tests for scrubber

This patch adds a place for unit tests for the scrubber. The test in
it addresses the change made at:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29405/

addresses bug: 1195423
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: I02da0847c3f93474f478c8740e4649280a02eae1

commit_message:
Updated LaunchConfig for AutoScaling UpdatePolicy

This is the first part of a series to implement support
for AutoScaling UpdatePolicy.

Updated LaunchConfiguration resource type to return
self.physical_resource_name() in FnGetRefId(). For both
InstanceGroup and AutoScalingGroup, the property
LaunchConfigurationName is added to the list of update allowed
properties. With this change, any property change to the
LaunchConfiguration resource will be result in a different
LaunchConfigurationName on reference resolution and thus will
trigger InstanceGroup and AutoScalingGroup to handle the update.

Change-Id: I94da8f7083b64873c511b953c6bc63dba2b51034
blueprint: as-update-policy

commit_message:
Tests for s3 and swift resources were extended

According to the description of the bug, the problem
is in the mechanism of dependencies. That is an internal
function Ref is not working properly. To repeat it, check
was added to the test templates (s3_test, swift_test). Thus,
the bug has not been reproduced.

Also, the method FnGetRefId in s3 and swift resources,
despite its name, returns the resource name in the format
'stack_name-resource_name-resource_id'. This is achieved
by the method physical_resource_name, that implemented in
superclass resource.Resource.

Bug 1202987

Change-Id: I0f85c39e10e8b455f93fdd768cd5e6ee14497277

commit_message:
Fix and enable Gating on H404

Enable gating on the Hacking H404 check - docstring
should start with a summary.

Change-Id: I80612a15bd11f689e9e9f4dc2ff812138630ddbd

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-15 23:34:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix SSH injection threat in 3PAR driver

The setqos ssh command was not built up correctly when the following
patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37697/ landed for cleaning up
the SSH calls from injection attacks in the 3PAR driver.

The command was in the following format causing the injection threat
due to the spaces in the second item in the list:
['setqos', '-io 5000 -bw 500M vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']
When it should actually be in the following format:
['setqos', '-io', '5000', '-bw', '500M', 'vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']

Change-Id: I69ed8dbca3af3ba56220891411b63331c1935373
Fixes: bug 1212884
"}]
commit_message:
Fix SSH injection threat in 3PAR driver

The setqos ssh command was not built up correctly when the following
patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37697/ landed for cleaning up
the SSH calls from injection attacks in the 3PAR driver.

The command was in the following format causing the injection threat
due to the spaces in the second item in the list:
['setqos', '-io 5000 -bw 500M vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']
When it should actually be in the following format:
['setqos', '-io', '5000', '-bw', '500M', 'vvset:vvs-JOHB2Oj0QJ2UaWatwbe7Bg']

Change-Id: I69ed8dbca3af3ba56220891411b63331c1935373
Fixes: bug 1212884

commit_message:
Use new olso fixture in CM tests

Before this change mox and cfg.CONF wasn't cleaned up correctly if
skipTest is called, because when skipTest is used teardown is not
called.

Now we use the oslo fixtures to setup oslo.config and mox to ensure the
cleanup is done between each tests.

Fixes bug #1211239

Change-Id: I5075c99106742859f0705b765f8ed4aa9be494d7
